Theories are indeed awesome! 

What I like most is that they open up the =
door for dynamic n:n dependencies
 between tests. That is something I never=
 liked wrt JExample: dependencies are
 limited to hardwired declarations in=
 the code.

My concern with the theories of JUnit 4.4  is that they introdu=
ce two    
 abstractions, @DataPoint and @Theory, and that none of these tw=
o abstractions
 returns reusable instances of the class under tests. To spe=
ak in JExample
 lingo you got pure producers and pure consumers only (with =
more flexible
 links between both though!) As a consequence, theories are l=
imited to
 dependency hierarchies of two levels only, while JExample can be=
 used to
 express dependency graphs of any depth. 

(Furthermore, of the tw=
o abstractions only theories are tests, so we cannot
 assert the validity o=
f data points before returning them. This should be
 fairly simple to solve=
 though.)

Running this will start without available input and thus run all=
 theories
 (above called @Example so users dont attempt to run this code in=
 JUnit)  
 without input, once inputs are available we can run turn by turn=
 all theories
 on all input. In fact, what we got now is a grammar for the =
creation of valid
 instances of the class under test.

However, since the n=
umber of valid stack instances is infinite (as is the case
 for any non-tri=
vial class) we have to stop somewhere if the test shall not
 run forever. 
=

What I'd like to emphasize is that JExample is not about dependencies only=
,
 its other major focus is *composable tests*. When writing tests (or
 exp=
erimenting on a REPL, alas we have none in Java...) you should be able to
 =
just say "gimme a valid instance of a stack with 3 elements" and the
 frame=
work goes and creates one for you. So the above example is maybe even
 clos=
er to my initial vision of JExample than what we have now. Using an
 assump=
tions to express that condition seems more flexile, whereas in JExample
 yo=
u would need to depend by name on another test that explicitly creates an
 =
elements with three instances. So that seems to confirm your "assumption
 s=
ufficiency" hypothesis, given there were composable theories.

Personally I=
 do not consider dependencies the major contribution of JExample
 (even tho=
ugh it is a nice selling point) but *composable tests* thanks to
 return va=
lues. The very idea that tests produce valid instances of the class
 under =
tests and that these instances should be reused by other tests. (Which
 of =
course opens up the Pandora's box of having to clone examples to avoid
